title: BP slides 1.7% after warning Hurricane Barry has hit production
text:
BP has revealed that revealed 100,000 barrels were lost per day to Hurricane Barry

BP has warned that Hurricane Barry’s trail of destruction in the Gulf of Mexico hit production and increased its tax rate.

The oil giant’s shares slipped 1.7 per cent, or 8.45p, to 493.55p after it revealed 100,000 barrels were lost per day to the storm in July.

The chaos forced the company to shut its rigs for two weeks, a trading update said yesterday.

And because the storm affected a low-tax region, it meant BP had to produce more oil in regions with higher tax rates, increasing its overall bill.

BP, which is in the middle of a massive programme to sell £8billion worth of assets, also warned it would have to take a one-off charge of between £1.6billion and £2.4billion in the third quarter.

This is because some assets it sold went for less than their value on the company’s balance sheet, meaning it had to take a writedown.

But it was well on the way to reaching its two-year target to sell the assets.
